definition: unrelenting/without stopping to rest
horse/CL:匹[pi3]/horse or cavalry piece in Chinese chess/knight in Western chess
surname Ma/abbr. for Malaysia 馬來西亞|马来西亚[Ma3 lai2 xi1 ya4]
(negative prefix)/not/no
to stop/to halt/to park (a car)
hoof/pig's trotters
variant of 蹄[ti2]

sentences.english: The stakes are higher, people are restless, poised for even greater transformation.
sentences.chinese: 人们正马不停蹄地准备迎接更大的变革。

sentences.english: The troops rushed to their destination without a single halt.
sentences.chinese: 部队马不停蹄地赶到了目的地。

sentences.english: Researchers believe that some hummingbirds fly non-stop over the Gulf of Mexico.
sentences.chinese: 研究员相信，一些蜂鸟会马不停蹄地飞越墨西哥湾。

sentences.english: He was traveling around the world for months on end.
sentences.chinese: 几个月来他马不停蹄地周游世界。

sentences.english: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton are campaigning in the state almost non-stop.
sentences.chinese: 奥巴马和克林顿参议员正马不停蹄地在这个州竞选。

sentences.english: Grant wasted no time. He quickly sent troops to fight the Confederate force blocking the Tennessee River.
sentences.chinese: 格兰特马不停蹄，迅速出兵，阻南军于田纳西州河畔。

sentences.english: And July is doing its best to outdo June.
sentences.chinese: 而且七月正在马不停蹄地超越六月。

sentences.english: You could whip around the world in a weekend if you flew non-stop.
sentences.chinese: 如果你马不停蹄的话，一周可以游完世界。

sentences.english: Meanwhile, President Bush was going out in full stride.
sentences.chinese: 与此同时，老布什总统正在马不停蹄地出访。

sentences.english: Then, I tirelessly went to a company the poem parents' home.
sentences.chinese: 然后，我马不停蹄就去了商诗父母的家里。

definition: to rush to/to hurry to
to hurry/to rush
to spur the horse to full speed (idiom)/to go as fast as possible
that very night/through the night/for several nights in a row
to hurry to (somewhere)
at top speed/at a tremendous lick
to set out on a journey
to set out (of troops)/departure/start date (of military expedition)
to travel to (a distant place)
hurriedly
to go straight to/to make a beeline for
to go on a journey/to leave
to win/to be victorious/to report a victory
to overtake/to catch up with/to hurry/to rush/to try to catch (the bus etc)/to drive (cattle etc) forward/to drive (sb) away/to avail oneself of (an opportunity)/until
day and night/regardless of the time of day or night
(of troops) to depart for/to head for
